events.summary: Francisco Tárrega made his grand entrance into the world in Villarreal, Spain, preparing to strum his way into history, likely screaming in perfect pitch.

After a minor eye incident that sent chills down his father's spine, Tárrega's family relocated to Castellón de la Plana, proving that a musician can't keep his eyes off their dreams, even when they might lose sight!

events.event: Studied at the Madrid Royal Conservatory
events.summary: With a guitar that could probably start a small revolution, Tárrega joined the conservatory to focus on his musical education, much to the relief of his father, who was probably tired of unexpected guitar solos at home.
During a concert, Tárrega found himself engaged to María José Rizo, proving that the power of music can lead to unexpected romantic harmonies!
Just after composing his way into life's next chapter, he tied the knot with María José, possibly hoping she could tolerate the sound of guitars in their house for the rest of their lives.
Inspired by a visit to Granada, Tárrega penned 'Recuerdos de la Alhambra', which was so beautiful that even the ghosts in the Alhambra probably took a moment to listen in awe!
With the sound of his guitar echoing through his thoughts, Tárrega completed his last piece, 'Oremus', ensuring that his legacy would not only be strummed but sung about for ages!
Tárrega passed away, leaving behind not just a legacy of guitar music but likely a few unfinished symphonies in the heads of friends who couldn’t stop humming his tunes.
Tárrega gave his first public performance, astonishing audiences and probably making them question how a human could produce such melodious sounds from mere wood and strings.
He moved to Madrid to study at the Royal Conservatory, where he likely learned to convince teachers that guitarists were just as cultured as pianists—as if that needed convincing.
Tárrega made his debut as a composer, and let's just say the music sheets probably had more fans than a social media influencer after their latest post.
Tárrega toured the United States, charming American audiences and making them rethink the guitar's status from 'backyard bonfire' to 'serious concert instrument.'
He began teaching, passing on his wisdom like Yoda with a six-string, ensuring generations of guitarists would always know the importance of right-hand technique and coffee breaks.
Tárrega retired, possibly tired of the same four chords and determined to finally finish that novel about a heroic guitar journey.

compositions.title: Estudio sobre una fuga de Bach
Variaciones sobre el Carnaval de Venecia de Paganini
